render.tex: \title{Pairs of lines in 3D} \\ %text Intersecting, Parallel or Skew %

reason.tex:
%text A pair of lines in $3D$ space may be classified as Intersecting, Parallel or Skew (non-intersecting and non-parallel). Here is the meaning of each with examples: %
\begin{align} L_1:&\dfrac{x-4}{3}=\dfrac{y-3}{7}=\dfrac{z-1}{1} \\ L_2:&\dfrac{x+1}{6}=\dfrac{y}{14}=\dfrac{z+3}{2} \\ L_3:&\dfrac{x-8}{2}=\dfrac{y-9}{8}=\dfrac{z}{3} \\ L_4:&\dfrac{x+3}{2}=\dfrac{y}{7}=\dfrac{z}{-14} \end{align} \\ \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{lll} \hline \text{Condition} & \text{Lines that...} & \text{Example} \\ \hline \text{Intersecting} & \text{meet at a point in space} & L_1,L_3.L_4 \\ \text{Parallel} & \text{are always a constant distance apart} & L_1, L_2 \\ \text{Skew} & \text{neither intersect nor are parallel} & L_2, L_3 \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} \\ %text Note: $L_1$ and $L_4$ are $\perp$ since their direction ratios have the relation $a_1a_2+b_1b_2+c_1c_2=0$ %
